titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS), Community and Resource Development, Acting Director, Office Files of Carl Anthony
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS), Community and Resource Development, Acting Director, Office Files of Carl Anthony FA507
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Brian Bleich and Nancy Ng Tam, The Winthrop Group

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 14:50:29 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS), Community and Resource Development, Acting Director, Office Files of Carl Anthony
did.abstract: The Asset Building and Community Development Program was established in October 1996 as part of a Foundation-wide program reorganization. The new program supported the work of a range of groups and individuals seeking to build the assets and capacities of poor communities through community-based activities, research, policy analysis, and advocacy. The Assets Program had three program units: Economic Development; Community and Resource Development (CRD); and Human Development and Reproductive Health. Carl Anthony joined the Ford Foundation as a Program Officer within the Assets Program's CRD Unit in 2001. In 2003, he became Deputy Director of Community and Resource Development and in 2004, Acting Director. As Program Officer, Anthony directed the Sustainable Metropolitan Communities Initiative (SMCI), the Foundation's grantmaking portfolio in equitable and sustainable community development. He also participated in making substantial cross-portfolio investments in Regional Equity Demonstrations (REDs, singular RED). The Office Files of Carl Anthony span in date from 1999 to 2006 and primarily document his work as Program Officer. The bulk of the collection consists of grantee files, primarily of SMCI and RED grant recipients. These files contain correspondence, project updates, conference materials, products of Ford-funded research, and background information about grantees and projects. The collection also contains files on trips, conferences and meetings Anthony attended in his capacity as Program Officer and Acting Director.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I. Sustainable Metropolitan Communities Initiative (SMCI) Files, 1998-2006
Series II. Regional Equity Demonstration (RED) Files, 1999-2006
Series IV. Trips, Conferences and Meetings, 2001-2005

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Office Files of Carl Anthony span in date from 1999 to 2006 and primarily document his work as Program Officer managing the Community and Resource Development Unit portfolio on regional equity and smart growth. The bulk of the collection consists of grantee files, primarily of recipients of grants under the Sustainable Metropolitan Communities Initiative (SMCI) and the Regional Equity Demonstrations (REDs). The collection also contains files on trips, conferences and meetings he attended in his capacity as Program Officer and Acting Director at Ford.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born in Philadelphia, Carl Anthony received a PhD in Architecture and Urban Planning from Columbia University. Between 1989 and 2001, he served as founding Executive Director of Urban Habitat, one of the nation's oldest environmental and economic justice organizations.

In 2001, he joined the Ford Foundation as a Program Officer within the Assets Program's Community and Resource Development (CRD) Unit. As Program Officer, he directed the Sustainable Metropolitan Communities Initiative (SMCI), the Foundation's grantmaking portfolio in equitable and sustainable community development. SMCI sought to alleviate concentrated poverty resulting from public policies and business practices that promoted economically segregated communities and ecologically unsustainable growth. It supported grantees engaged in a wide range of work, including research and discussions on urban sprawl and smart growth; leadership and capacity building; policy development; and strategic communication influencing more equitable regional resource allocation.

As a CRD Unit program officer, Mr. Anthony also participated in making substantial cross-portfolio investments in Regional Equity Demonstrations (REDs, singular RED). REDs were practical learning applications and demonstrations of the Foundation's regional approach to community development and urban revitalization. Then CRD Unit Director Cynthia Miller originally initiated RED as a unit-wide initiative designed to foster substantial cross-portfolio investments focused on racial justice and social equity in the City of Camden, New Jersey and its surrounding communities. REDs were initiated at four other locations: Richmond, California; Baltimore, Maryland; Detroit, Michigan; and Atlanta, Georgia. In Camden, New Jersey, where the majority of grant funds were invested, the Foundation promoted its regional equity agenda through targeted investments in the areas of real estate development, employment opportunities, public sector capacity, and civic engagement. Mr. Anthony continued the RED initiative through his tenure as CRD Unit Deputy Director in 2003 and Acting Director in 2004. With the selection of Suzanne Siskel as CRD Unit Director in 2006, RED came under the management of the single grant portfolio, SMCI.
In 2006, Mr. Anthony left the Foundation to become a Visiting Scholar and Ford Foundation Senior Fellow in the Department of Geography at the University of California Berkeley.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Asset Building and Community Development Program was established in October 1996 as part of a Foundation-wide program reorganization. The new program brought together four previously separate Foundation programs in Urban Poverty, Rural Poverty and Resources, Reproductive Health and Population, and Program Related Investments. It supported the work of a range of groups and individuals seeking to build the assets and capacities of poor communities through community-based activities, research, policy analysis, and advocacy. The Assets Program had three program units: Economic Development; Community and Resource Development; and Human Development and Reproductive Health. In 2009, the Asset Building and Community Development Program became the Economic Opportunity and Assets Program.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

did.unittitle: Sustainable Metropolitan Communities Initiative (SMCI) Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of subject files documenting the work of Sustainable Metropolitan Communities Initiative (SMCI) grantees. Files are arranged alphabetically by name of grantee or project and contain correspondence, conference materials, products of Ford-funded research, and background information about grantees and projects. The bulk of correspondence pertains to project updates and conference information grantees sent to Mr. Anthony. Files on conferences held by grantees, grantmaking partners or the Ford Foundation that Mr. Anthony kept with his SMCI files are included in this series. Additional conference files can be found in Series IV: Trips, Conferences and Meetings.

Regional Equity Demonstration (RED) Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of files documenting the Ford Foundation Community and Resource Development (CRD) Unit's Regional Equity Demonstrations (REDs). Although there are a few files on other RED project locations, files on the RED project in Camden, New Jersey constitute the bulk of the series. Camden RED files consist of correspondence, meeting materials, proposals, and background information on Camden, grantees and projects. Several files document various RED staff meetings as well as the Foundation's partnership and collaboration with The Reinvestment Fund (TRF), the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation (MDRC) and the Annie E. Casey Foundation.

In addition, there are three files pertaining to the work of consultant David Rusk. Mr. Rusk prepared activity reports, recommendations, and papers in his role as advisor to the CRD Unit in national strategies for regional reform and as a resource for Ford grantees in Atlanta, Baltimore, Detroit, Philadelphia and Camden.

Grant-Related Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of files relating to grants Mr. Anthony managed within his program area of regional equity and smart growth. Mr. Anthony kept these files as part of his General Files. They are maintained as a separate series because it is unclear whether these grants were issued as part of the SMCI or RED initiatives. Files contain correspondence and memoranda along with attached proposals, meeting notes, agenda and background materials regarding proposed or then-ongoing grant activity. One highlight is a file that documents Mr. Anthony's involvement in the creation of the Funder's Network, a resource for foundations, nonprofit organizations and other partners working to address problems resulting from suburban sprawl and urban disinvestment.

Trips, Conferences and Meetings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of files Mr. Anthony maintained of various conferences and meetings he attended on behalf of the Foundation. Files contain correspondence, agenda, notes, and background information for conferences held by other philanthropies such as the Land Bank Authority Forum in Flint, Michigan; conferences held with some Ford Foundation support such as the Funder's Network Conference in New Orleans; and internal Foundation events such as the Environment and Development Affinity Group workshop in China. A few files document meetings held at the Foundation building in New York, including the Ford Foundation Community Benefits Roundtable. There are also records of Mr. Anthony's travels for Foundation-related reasons such as his site visit to the Center for Heirs' Property Preservation in Charleston, South Carolina.

Writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a book chapter titled "Race, Poverty and the Humane Metropolis: Revisiting William H. Whyte" that Mr. Anthony wrote for The Human Metropolis: People and Nature in the Twenty-First Century City edited by Rutherford H. Platt (Amherst: University of Massachusetts Press and Lincoln Institute of Land Policy, Cambridge, 2006).

did.unittitle: "Race, Poverty and the Humane Metropolis: Revisiting William H. Whyte," The Human Metropolis: People and Nature in the 21st Century City (published book chapter)
